titlestmt.subtitle: Papers of Pauline Kael, 1939-2001, at the Lilly Library, Indiana University
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Maya Lerman.

note.p: Trustees of Indiana University. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-02-18 22:07:21 -0500.

did.abstract: The Kael mss., ca. 1939-2001, consists of the papers and correspondence of film critic and author Pauline Kael, 1919-2001.
did.physloc: ALF (Auxiliary Library Facility); Wells - Map Case (Box 124)

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Pauline Kael, 1919-2001, was an American film critic and author. She was born on June 19, 1919 in Petaluma, California. Her family moved to San Francisco when she was eight. She attended the University of California, Berkeley from 1936-1940 during which time she broadcast film reviews on radio station KPFA and managed the Berkeley Cinema Guild Theaters. In 1965 she moved permanently to the east coast where she freelanced for various magazines such as Life and New Republic. McCall's hired her briefly as a full-time film critic, but it was rumored that she was fired for writing a scathing review of The Sound of Music. Kael was best known as the film critic for The New Yorker where she was hired in 1968. She resigned in 1979 to become executive consultant on film projects for Paramount Pictures Corporation. She soon became disenchanted and returned to The New Yorker in 1980 where she stayed until her retirement in 1991. She published numerous books. Most were compilations of her New Yorker columns, including I Lost it at the Movies, Kiss Kiss Bang Bang, Going Steady, Deeper Into Movies, Reeling, When the Lights Go Down, Hooked, Movie Love, and For Keeps. One of her lengthier columns in The New Yorker became the basis for her book The Citizen Kane Book: Raising Kane which also contained the shooting script for the film. She received numerous awards for her criticism: The 1970 American Academy of Arts and Letters award for literature, The National Book Award in 1974, as well as awards from P.E.N. in 1996 and the 1999 National Book Critics Circle's Ivan Sandrof Award. In addition, she received honorary degrees from various colleges and universities. Kael died on September 3, 2001 at the age of 82.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence is comprised of personal letters from colleagues and friends, those relating to her writings, and many fan letters. Very few copies of Kael's own letters are present. The Director's files contain notes taken by Kael during the film screenings, typescript or holograph drafts of articles about the films by Kael and others, and related materials such as press kits, stills and clippings. The Writings section includes holograph drafts, typescripts and notes for her articles and books, as well as research and production materials, and advertisements. Files concerning her stint at KPFA and tear sheets of most of her "Current Cinema" columns are also present. Screenplays and play scripts submitted for her perusal make up most of the Writings by Others section. Kael clipped thousands of articles from magazines and newspapers. These clippings comprise the bulk of the Subjects file. Items in the Memorabilia section include Kael's awards, certificates and diplomas, programs from various film festivals and photographs. Among the audio-visual tapes are recordings from KPFA broadcasts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into the following series: I. Correspondence; II. Directors; III. Writings by Kael; IV. Writings by Others; V. Subjects; VI. Memorabilia; VII. Audiovisual. An inventory is available.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Kael mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into two sections: Alphabetical and Chronological. Each name in the Alphabetical section is followed by the year or range of years of the correspondence. Some related materials may also be present, such as photographs or printed materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Chronological section is not indexed. Additional correspondence may be found throughout the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Aranged alphabetically by director. Film titles are listed alphabetically under director's name. One folder per film title or subject, unless otherwise indicated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The notes may be those taken by Kael, holographs or typescripts of her reviews, and/or articles by Kael and others. The photographs are mostly stills. Printed items are generally "Cinema Texas program notes" (University of Texas at Austin) or "The Art Film" containing descriptive notes often written by Kael. Programs are printed programs or descriptions of a film for film festivals and other showings. Clippings may also include photocopies or print-outs of articles from the internet. Oversize materials are filed in Boxes 113-116, 121 and 124.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged as follows: "An Index...," early writings, articles for magazines, book reviews, interviews (with Kael), lectures/speeches, panel discussions, film series, notes, and miscellaneous. Most of the Kael's notes may be found under the specific film title filed throughout Series II. Directors.

did.unittitle: "An Index to the Film Reviews of Pauline Kael"by Claire Dorton

did.physdesc: Contains complete magazines and/or tear sheets.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title of magazine or journal.

did.unittitle: Conversations: The Wild Man, Remembering Peckinpah.
Current Cinema. Mostly tear sheets and some corrected page proofs.
did.physdesc: (9 folders) (For "Current Cinema" written by other authors, see: IV. Writings by Others. Current Cinema)

did.unittitle: Concerning the film "Lonely Boy," moderated by Kael at the Monterey Peninsula College Film Seminar

unittitle.emph: A Brash Young Man: A Film Story.
The Citizen Kane Book: Raising Kane

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically and chiefly concern Orson Welles' authorship of Citizen Kane and other projects, as well as the attempt by Robert Hughes to publish the Kane script. Includes single letters by Joseph Cotten and Herman Mankiewicz, and several from Howard Koch and Welles.

did.physdesc: Original storyboard sketch of nurse overhearing Kane's last word: "Rosebud." Received from Maurice Zuberano, sketch artist for the film

unittitle.emph: The Citizen Kane Book: Raising Kane (cont.)

did.physdesc: Notes and other materials concerning publication of Citizen Kane script

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly typescripts of play scripts and screenplays, and articles. Arranged alphabetically by author, then title of work. Some titles contain related correspondence. Tear sheets of The New Yorker column "Current Cinema," printed materials and posters complete this section. Other writings may be found in series I. Correspondence and series II. Directors.

did.unittitle: What is Cinema Draft pages and Uncorrected Proof with corrections and comments penciled in by Kael
Chesler, Marc and Gail Leslie Fisher
Don't the Moon Look Lonesome: A Novel in Blues and Swing
Feed the Monkey: A Farce of Habits
Emperor of the Sky, Neon Volcano, Valley of the Locusts (The Stark Truth)
Cuckoo Hollers: America Found and Lost in Bob Dylan's Basement Tapes
The Girl Who Sang with the Beatles
Beasts, Babes, Bikers & Bloodletters: an Encyclopedia of Drive-In Performers
The Famous Teddy Z, Episode: Al Gets a New Job (television)
A New American Master (concerning John Guare)
Nanny Wins from Piccadilly Circus to Times Square
Nurse Lambert's Strange Flight from Love
The Man Who was Both Proud and Shy
An American Film Institute: A Proposal (offprint)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Written by various authors. Later columns principally written by Penelope Gilliatt.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically, 1937, 1950-2000 (9 folders) (For "Current Cinema" written by Kael, see: III. Writings. Articles for The New Yorker magazine. Current Cinema)

did.physdesc: Mostly magazines with penciled editorial comments by Kael.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title of magazine or journal. No list available. (12 folders)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Subject headings were assigned by Kael for the most part and are arranged alphabetically, after the articles about her. Mostly clippings, but may include photographs and other printed materials. One folder per subject unless otherwise indicated.

did.unittitle: Articles concerning Kael. Clippings, magazines, etc. No list available:
The American Academy of Arts and Letters award in Literature.
George Polk Memorial Award for Criticism for 1970.
The National Book National Book Award for arts and letters. "A Celebration of Letters: The Twenty-Fifth Anniversary of the National Book Awards";
Newswomen's Club of New York, Inc., Front Page Award for Best Magazine Column.
Phi Beta Kappa certificate from Radcliffe College.
Newswomen's Club of New York, Inc., Front Page Award for Distinguished Journalism.
Mel Novikoff Award, accepted on Kael's behalf by Michael Sragow at the 34th San Francisco International Film Festival.
Los Angeles Film Critics Association, annual achievement awards, special award accepted by Marcia Nasatir for Kael.
The Independent Feature Project Gotham Award.
PEN Center, USA West, literary award for Body of Work in Criticism.
The National Book Critics Circle's Ivan Sandrof Award for Contribution to American Arts & Letters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged by format: reel-to-reel audiotapes, audio cassettes and one 16mm film. May not be used in present formats.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Available electronically through Indiana University's Media Collections Online.
